text:
CHRIS MOODY: You
might have heard

of Bassem Youssef,
the Arab world's
most well-known satirist.

As the host of an
Egyptian comedy show,
he pilloried the ruling elite.

That is, until he had
to flee his own country.

BASSEM YOUSSEF: When I was
driving through the airport

I was thinking, I mean, just
like a couple of years ago,

I was the biggest
name in this country,
and now I have to escape.

At least we did something, and
now I have to run for my life.

CHRIS MOODY: Youssef
was a surgeon

in Cairo when the Egyptian
revolution broke out in 2011.

In his off time, he
started a YouTube

channel from his laundry
room, and it went viral.

That led to a nationwide
television deal

and notice from Jon Stewart,
who appeared on the program.

On his show, Youssef mocked
the Muslim Brotherhood

and the leader of the Army,
General Abdel Fattah el-Sisi,
who eventually became president.

Feeling threatened when
an Egyptian court ordered

him to pay millions
over his jokes,
Youssef escaped the country.

BASSEM YOUSSEF: Went back home,
packed as much as possible
in two bags.

Passed by my father on
my way to the airport.

Because I couldn't talk
to him on the phone,

I don't know if our
phones were tapped or not.

And I told him, I'm leaving
right now, I'm sorry.

And I guess I'll see
you when I see you.

I didn't even have time to
say goodbye to my brother.
- There, there, there!

CHRIS MOODY: Youssef is
now an immigrant living
in Los Angeles with his family.

He has a new book called
"Revolution for Dummies,"

and a documentary
about his time in Egypt
called "Tickling Giants."

BASSEM YOUSSEF: I decided
to come here to America,

start from scratch, from
zero, like from a zero point

where I'm speaking to
a different people,
different language.

Again restarting for the
third time, a third career.

It is interesting and it's
scary at the same time.

CHRIS MOODY: Youssef
is famous worldwide,

and he's been celebrated
on national television.

STEPHEN COLBERT: Please
welcome Bassem Youssef.
Bassem, thank you so much.

BASSEM YOUSSEF:
Thank you so much.
Who the hell is this guy?

CHRIS MOODY: But his future
in America still isn't clear.

BASSEM YOUSSEF: I think
I have the usual concerns

like even Americans in
the United States have.

Will I be able to
make it or not?

I want to us that
momentum to continue

to have my place under the
sun in the American media.
I take improv classes.
I take acting classes.

I do, sometimes I
do cartoon video.

I do auditions like anybody and
get rejected like everybody.
So it is being busy.
It is good.

CHRIS MOODY: If leaders
are so tough and powerful,
why can't they take a joke?

BASSEM YOUSSEF: We
come from an area

where societies are not
allowed to question.

They're not allowed to
speak against authority,

whether that authority was a
family authority, a business

authority, school
authority, or country

authority, religious
authority, military authority.
It's a sin.
It's like you're betraying them.

It's like how dare you
speak about our leader.
We broke that taboo.
We actually spoke up.

We spoke up against
presidents, against leaders,

against institutions that
were absolutely untouchable.

CHRIS MOODY: The Youssef family
moved to the United States

during an interesting
time politically.

He's often asked about
President Donald Trump.

And as if it were some
cosmic cruel joke,

Trump recently invited Youssef's
tormentor, Egyptian President
Sisi, to the White House.

DONALD TRUMP: He's
done a fantastic job
in a very difficult situation.

BASSEM YOUSSEF: It's funny
to see like which one of them

is looking at the
other as a role model.

One of them wanted
to-- like how can you
have so unquestioned powers.

And the other one like, how
can I be as stupid as you?

I'm not worried about Trump
as much as the atmosphere
that he has created.

The racism that he has enabled,
the hate that he has made it

a mainstream, that will
stay long after Trump.

- This is what
democracy looks like.

BASSEM YOUSSEF: It's amazing
to see all of this activism.

I'd like to see
like 10 times more

of snarking and making
fun of these activists,
but what does it lead to?

I'm just like
worried that people

are resolving to just
sharing and retweeting
and reposting stuff.

But the fight is every two
years, is in your mid-terms,
it's in your elections.

If you do the initial activism
and you don't do that,
that's horrible.

Satire is great, but it
doesn't do anything by itself.

CHRIS MOODY: Do you
consider yourself in exile?
BASSEM YOUSSEF: No.

I considered myself in exile
even when I was in Egypt.

You can be in your own country
and you can be in an exile

if you can connect with
the people around you.

And I think you can
make your exile home.

If you find a certain
success there,

if you find your way,
your path, your voice,
you know, that makes it home.
